cmCourseInfo.description: Transforming archaeological results into statements about people and their life ways. Covers basic archaeological theory, including research design, sampling, stratigraphy, seriation, formation and testing or evaluation of hypotheses, regional analyses. Introduces some of the major schools of archaeological theory, including New Archaeology and Post-Processual Archaeology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Archaeological Interpretation

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are asynchronous (1.0-1.2 hours per week), supplemented by synchronous discussions and activities centred on the weekly readings and lecture materials (up to 1 hours per week). Lectures will take the form of recorded videos that can be viewed prior to the weekly class meetings, along with slides and readings distributed in a digital course packet through Quercus. Synchronous activities include discussion in small groups, brief presentations to the class, online forums, and other activities following up on recent readings and lectures. Assessment will be based on a series of short written assignments, discussions and short presentations during class time, and two time-limited but open-note tests to be taken on Quercus. The instructor will hold office hours at regular intervals each week.

cmCourseInfo.description: An analysis of ethics in contemporary archaeology that covers reburial and repatriation, interpretation of the archaeological record in the context of historically oppressed groups, ethnic minorities, and non-western societies, the ethics of collecting and managing cultural property, relationships with the media, the debates surrounding looting, and other issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Archaeology, Ethics, and the Public

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students can access recordings of invited lectures after synchronously delivered, but are required to participate in the online-synchronous discussion of each class. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in discussion.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Jul 20, 2020: Course offered as Online - Synchronous

cmCourseInfo.description: Techniques for making archaeological data meaningful after excavation or survey. Archaeological measurements, compilation of data, database design, archaeological systematics, and sampling theory in the context of lithics, pottery, floral, faunal and other archaeological remains.
cmCourseInfo.title: Archaeological Laboratory
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT200Y1 and a half statistics course (e.g. GGR270H1*, STA220H1, STA221H1, STA257H1, STA261H1, ANTC35H3**. Note: *Geography Pre- or co-requisites waived for Anthropology and Archaeology students; ** to be taken at the Scarborough Campus

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is planned as an online course with at-home assignments. Lectures and demonstrations for lab sessions will be given as 1.5-hour online videos each week, asynchronously. For some labs, there will also be online videos to demonstrate particular methods. Students should watch the videos in the week that they are posted. Some of the laboratories will involve fairly simple tasks and measurements that students can carry out at home with minimal equipment and supplies. Others will involve analyzing datasets after having watched videos about how the data were collected. Other labs that are not practical to deliver online, such as flintknapping and pottery technology, will be replaced by video demonstrations. Students will have opportunities for synchronous online office hours before the deadline for submitting each lab report to ask questions and obtain clarifications about lab instructions. Half-hour sessions for discussion and questions about the lectures or labs will use the chat functions on Quercus. Students will need to be able to read PDFs, watch YouTube videos and PowerPoint slides, use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra), to access a scanner, camera or phone to scan hand-drawn graphs, or software for making graphs digitally, and to use spreadsheet software such as Excel or Numbers. Two tests (early December and late March) will be timed and online.

courses.name: Prehistory of the Near East (formerly ANT360Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: From earliest times through the rise of complex hunter-gatherers, and the food producing revolution to politically complex societies in Southwest Asia.
cmCourseInfo.title: Prehistory of the Near East (formerly ANT360Y1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

For each week there will be two taped lectures (asynchronous) of forty minutes each.  The first will present an overview of the time period covered and the second will cover key points in the assigned articles.  There will also be a forty minute discussion component focusing on the assigned articles (synchronous).   We will be taking advantage of the unusual circumstances to include guests in our discussion that will often include the authors of the articles we are discussing. Course assignments will be based on reading articles and will include two short paper and one timed writing assignment during which students will have access to their notes and readings.  Students will be able to schedule office hours with the instructor as needed.  Students will also be expected to sign up for three small group chats with the instructor (half an hour each) over the course of the semester.

cmCourseInfo.description: Opportunity for students participating in non-degree credit archaeological digs to submit reports, field notes and term papers for degree credit. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Field Archaeology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of Undergraduate Co-ordinator and Supervisor

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Cultural Resource Management and Professional Archaeology in North America

sections.name: LEC9101
sections.subTitle: Cultural Resource Management and Professional Archaeology in North America

cmCourseInfo.description: Taught by an advanced PhD student or postdoctoral fellow, and based on his or her doctoral research and area of expertise, this course presents a unique opportunity to explore intensively a particular Archaeology topic in-depth. Topics vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Emerging Scholarship (Archaeology)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Classes will be structured with 60–75 minutes of lecture, followed by 35–50 minutes of discussion and/or practical sessions. Recordings of lectures will be made available for students to view asynchronously AFTER the synchronous session has ended. NOTE: discussions/practical sessions will not be recorded.  It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities (e.g., discussion/practical sessions).

cmCourseInfo.description: Laboratory or practical research on an archaeological project that emphasizes methods and research design in archaeology. Students must obtain the consent of a Supervisor before enrolling. Students are required to give an oral presentation of research results to an open meeting of the Archaeology Centre at the conclusion of the course. Application must be made to the Anthropology Department. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Archaeology Research Practicum
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A minimum of 14 credits, permission of Supervisor and Undergraduate Coordinator.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
